entities.description: Rene Lepage de Sainte-Claire is the lord-founder of the town of Rimouski, province of Quebec, in Canada.

entities.title: Rimouski
entities.description: Rimouski (/ˌrɪmu'ski/) is a city in Quebec, Canada. Rimouski is located in the Bas-Saint-Laurent region, at the mouth of the Rimouski River. It has a population of 48,664. Rimouski is the site of Université du Québec à Rimouski (UQAR), the Cégep de Rimouski and the Music Conservatory. It is also the home of some ocean sciences research centres.

heading: Deaths
txt: Victor-Maurice, comte de Broglie, French general (b. 1647)

entities.title: Victor-Maurice, comte de Broglie
entities.description: Victor-Maurice, comte de Broglie was a French soldier and general.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrew Hamilton, Scottish-American lawyer and politician (b. 1676)

entities.title: Andrew Hamilton (lawyer)
entities.description: Andrew Hamilton was a Scottish lawyer in the Thirteen Colonies, where he finally settled in Philadelphia. He was best known for his legal victory on behalf of the printer and newspaper publisher John Peter Zenger. His involvement with the 1735 decision in New York helped to establish that truth is a defense to an accusation of libel. His eloquent defense concluded with saying that the press has "a

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre de Rigaud, Marquis de Vaudreuil-Cavagnial, Canadian-French politician, Governor General of New France (b. 1698)

entities.title: Pierre de Rigaud, Marquis de Vaudreuil-Cavagnial
entities.description: Pierre de Rigaud de Vaudreuil de Cavagnial, marquis de Vaudreuil was a Canadian-born colonial governor of Canada in North America. He was governor of French Louisiana (1743–1753) and in 1755 became the last Governor-General of New France. In 1759 and 1760 the British conquered the colony in the Seven Years' War.

entities.title: Governor General of New France
entities.description: Governor General of New France was the vice-regal post in New France from 1663 until 1760 and was the last French vice-regal post. It was replaced by the British post of Governor of the Province of Quebec following the fall of New France. While the districts of Montreal and Trois-Rivières had their own governors, the Governor General of New France and the Governor of the district of Quebec were th

heading: Deaths
txt: John Burgoyne, English general and politician (b. 1723)

entities.title: John Burgoyne
entities.description: General John Burgoyne was a British army officer, dramatist and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1761 to 1792. He first saw action during the Seven Years' War when he participated in several battles, most notably during the Portugal Campaign of 1762.

heading: Deaths
txt: Timothy Ruggles, American lawyer, jurist, and politician (b. 1711)

entities.title: Timothy Ruggles
entities.description: Timothy Dwight Ruggles was an American colonial military leader, jurist and politician. He was a delegate to the Stamp Act Congress of 1765, and later a loyalist during the American Revolutionary War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Adam Duncan, 1st Viscount Duncan, Scottish admiral (b. 1731)

entities.title: Adam Duncan, 1st Viscount Duncan
entities.description: Admiral Adam Duncan, 1st Viscount Duncan, KB was a British admiral who defeated the Dutch fleet off Camperdown on 11 October 1797. This victory is considered one of the most significant actions in naval history.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kristjan Jaak Peterson, Estonian poet and author (b. 1801)

entities.title: Kristjan Jaak Peterson
entities.description: Kristian Jaak Peterson also known as Christian Jacob Petersohn, was an Estonian poet, commonly regarded as a herald of Estonian national literature and the founder of modern Estonian poetry. He died of tuberculosis aged 21.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacob Aall, Norwegian economist, historian, and politician (b. 1773)

entities.title: Jacob Aall
entities.description: Jacob Aall was a Norwegian politician, historian, landowner and government economist.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Vianney, French priest and saint (b. 1786)

entities.title: John Vianney
entities.description: John Vianney, venerated as Saint John Vianney, was a French Catholic priest who is venerated in the Catholic Church as a saint and as the patron saint of parish priests. He is often referred to as the "Curé d'Ars", internationally known for his priestly and pastoral work in his parish in Ars, France, because of the radical spiritual transformation of the community and its surroundings. Catholics a

heading: Deaths
txt: Viktor Hartmann, Russian architect and painter (b. 1834)

entities.title: Viktor Hartmann
entities.description: Viktor Alexandrovich Hartmann was a Russian architect and painter. He was associated with the Abramtsevo Colony, purchased and preserved beginning in 1870 by Savva Mamontov, and the Russian Revival.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Christian Andersen, Danish novelist, short story writer, and poet (b. 1805)

entities.title: Hans Christian Andersen
entities.description: Hans Christian Andersen, in Denmark usually called H.C. Andersen, was a Danish author. Although a prolific writer of plays, travelogues, novels, and poems, he is best remembered for his fairy tales.

heading: Deaths
txt: Samuel J. Tilden, American lawyer and politician, 25th Governor of New York (b. 1814)

entities.title: Samuel J. Tilden
entities.description: Samuel Jones Tilden  was an American politician who served as the 25th Governor of New York and was the Democratic candidate for president in the disputed 1876 United States presidential election. Tilden was the second presidential candidate to lose the election despite winning the popular vote and is the only person to win a majority of the popular vote in a United States presidential election bu

entities.title: Governor of New York
entities.description: The governor of New York is the head of state and head of government of the U.S. state of New York. The governor is the head of the executive branch of New York's state government and the commander-in-chief of the state's military forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Isaac Levitan, Russian painter and educator (b. 1860)

entities.title: Isaac Levitan
entities.description: Isaac Ilyich Levitan was a classical Russian landscape painter who advanced the genre of the "mood landscape".

heading: Deaths
txt: Jules Lemaître, French playwright and critic (b. 1853)

entities.title: Jules Lemaître
entities.description: François Élie Jules Lemaître was a French critic and dramatist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dave Gregory, Australian cricketer and umpire (b. 1845)

entities.title: Dave Gregory (cricketer)
entities.description: David William Gregory was an Australian cricketer. A right-handed batsman, Gregory was the first Australian national cricket captain, leading the side for the first three recognised Test matches between England and Australia in March and April 1877 and January 1879. Gregory was also the captain of the New South Wales team, notably during the Sydney Riot of 1879 when he rebelled against an unpopula

heading: Deaths
txt: Enver Pasha, Ottoman general and politician (b. 1881)

entities.title: Enver Pasha
entities.description: Ismail Enver Pasha was an Ottoman military officer who formed one-third of the dictatorial triumvirate known as the "Three Pashas" in the Ottoman Empire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred Henry Maurer, American painter (b. 1868)

entities.title: Alfred Henry Maurer
entities.description: Alfred Henry Maurer was an American modernist painter. He exhibited his work in avant-garde circles internationally and in New York City during the early twentieth century. Highly respected today, his work met with little critical or commercial success in his lifetime, and he died, a suicide, at the age of sixty-four.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pearl White, American actress (b. 1889)

entities.title: Pearl White
entities.description: Pearl Fay White was an American stage and film actress. White began her career on the stage at the age of six, and later moved on to silent films appearing in a number of popular serials.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ze'ev Jabotinsky, Ukrainian-American general, journalist, and activist (b. 1880)

entities.title: Ze'ev Jabotinsky
entities.description: Ze'ev Jabotinsky,, was a Russian Jewish Revisionist Zionist leader, author, poet, orator, soldier, and founder of the Jewish Self-Defense Organization in Odessa. With Joseph Trumpeldor, he co-founded the Jewish Legion of the British army in World War I. Later he established several Jewish organizations in Palestine, including Betar, Hatzohar, and the Irgun.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mihály Babits, Hungarian poet and author (b. 1883)

entities.title: Mihály Babits
entities.description: Mihály Babits was a Hungarian poet, writer and translator. His poems are well known for their intense religious themes. His novels such as “The Children of Death” (1927) explore psychological problems.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alberto Franchetti, Italian composer and educator (b. 1860)

entities.title: Alberto Franchetti
entities.description: Alberto Franchetti was an Italian opera composer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Krzysztof Kamil Baczyński, Polish soldier and poet (b. 1921)

entities.title: Krzysztof Kamil Baczyński
entities.description: Krzysztof Kamil Baczyński, was a Polish poet and Home Army soldier, one of the most well known of the Generation of Columbuses, the young generation of Polish poets, of whom several perished in the Warsaw Uprising and during the German occupation of Poland.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Cain Sr., Australian politician, 34th Premier of Victoria (b. 1882)

entities.title: John Cain (senior)
entities.description: John Cain was an Australian politician, who became the 34th premier of Victoria, and was the first Labor Party leader to win a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly. He is the only premier of Victoria to date whose son has also served as premier.

entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

heading: Deaths
txt: Washington Luís, Brazilian lawyer and politician, 13th President of Brazil (b. 1869)

entities.title: President of Brazil
entities.description: The president of Brazil, officially the President of the Federative Republic of Brazil or simply the President of the Republic, is both the head of state and the head of government of Brazil. The president leads the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the Brazilian Armed Forces. The presidential system was established in 1889, upon the proclamation of the re

heading: Deaths
txt: Ethel Anderson, Australian poet, author, and painter (b. 1883)

entities.title: Ethel Anderson
entities.description: Ethel Campbell Louise Anderson was an early twentieth century Australian poet, essayist, novelist and painter. She considered herself to be mainly a poet, but is now best appreciated for her witty and ironic stories. Anderson has been described as "a high-profile author, artist, art commentator and emissary for modernism".

heading: Deaths
txt: József Révai, Hungarian politician, Hungarian Minister of Education (b. 1898)

entities.title: József Révai
entities.description: József Révai was a Hungarian communist politician and statesman.

entities.title: Minister of Education (Hungary)
entities.description: The Minister of Human Capacities of Hungary is a member of the Hungarian cabinet and the head of the Ministry of Human Capacities. The current minister of human capacities is Miklós Kásler.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marilyn Monroe, American model and actress (b. 1926)

entities.title: Marilyn Monroe
entities.description: Marilyn Monroe was an American actress, model, and singer. Famous for playing comedic "blonde bombshell" characters, she became one of the most popular sex symbols of the 1950s and early 1960s and was emblematic of the era's sexual revolution. She was a top-billed actress for only a decade, but her films grossed $200 million by the time of her death in 1962. Long after her death, she continues to

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Smith, English cricketer (b. 1908)

entities.title: Peter Smith (cricketer, born 1908)
entities.description: Thomas Peter Bromley Smith was an English cricketer, who played for Essex and England. Smith was one of the five Wisden Cricketers of the Year in 1947. An all-rounder, Smith played for Essex from 1929 to 1951.

heading: Deaths
txt: Enrique Angelelli, Argentinian bishop and martyr (b. 1923)

entities.title: Enrique Angelelli
entities.description: Enrique Ángel Angelelli Carletti was a bishop of the Catholic Church in Argentina who was assassinated during the Dirty War for his involvement with social issues.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roy Thomson, 1st Baron Thomson of Fleet, Canadian-English publisher (b. 1894)

heading: Deaths
txt: Edgar Adrian, 1st Baron Adrian, English physiologist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1889)

entities.title: Edgar Adrian, 1st Baron Adrian
entities.description: Edgar Douglas Adrian, 1st Baron Adrian was an English electrophysiologist and recipient of the 1932 Nobel Prize for Physiology, won jointly with Sir Charles Sherrington for work on the function of neurons. He provided experimental evidence for the all-or-none law of nerves.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Melvyn Douglas, American actor (b. 1901)

entities.title: Melvyn Douglas
entities.description: Melvyn Douglas was an American actor. Douglas came to prominence in the 1930s as a suave leading man, perhaps best typified by his performance in the romantic comedy Ninotchka (1939) with Greta Garbo. Douglas later played mature and fatherly characters, as in his Academy Award–winning performances in Hud (1963) and Being There (1979) and his Academy Award–nominated performance in I Never Sang for

heading: Deaths
txt: Bruce Goff, American architect, designed the Boston Avenue Methodist Church (b. 1904)

entities.title: Bruce Goff
entities.description: Bruce Alonzo Goff was an American architect, distinguished by his organic, eclectic, and often flamboyant designs for houses and other buildings in Oklahoma and elsewhere.

entities.title: Boston Avenue Methodist Church
entities.description: The Boston Avenue United Methodist Church, located in downtown Tulsa, Oklahoma, and completed in 1929, is considered to be one of the finest examples of ecclesiastical Art Deco architecture in the United States, and has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places. Built by a congregation of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, it was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1999.

heading: Deaths
txt: Don Whillans, English rock climber and mountaineer (b. 1933)

entities.title: Don Whillans
entities.description: Donald Desbrow Whillans was an English rock climber and mountaineer. He climbed with Joe Brown and Chris Bonington on many new routes, and was considered the technical equal of both.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ettore Maserati, Italian engineer and businessman (b. 1894)

entities.title: Ettore Maserati
entities.description: Ettore Maserati was an Italian automotive engineer, one of five brothers who founded the Maserati firm in Bologna 1914. He was born in Voghera.

heading: Deaths
txt: Seichō Matsumoto, Japanese author (b. 1909)

entities.title: Seichō Matsumoto
entities.description: Seichō Matsumoto  was a Japanese writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Geoff Hamilton, English gardener, author, and television host (b. 1936)

entities.title: Geoff Hamilton
entities.description: Geoffrey Stephen Hamilton was an English gardener, broadcaster and author, best known as presenter of BBC television's Gardeners' World in the 1980s and 1990s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jeanne Calment, French super-centenarian; holds records for the world's substantiated longest-lived person (b. 1875)

entities.title: Jeanne Calment
entities.description: Jeanne Louise Calment was a French supercentenarian and the oldest human whose age is well-documented, with a lifespan of 122 years and 164 days. Her longevity attracted media attention and medical studies of her health and lifestyle.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yury Artyukhin, Russian colonel, engineer, and astronaut (b. 1930)

entities.title: Yury Artyukhin
entities.description: Yuri Petrovich Artyukhin was a Soviet Russian cosmonaut and engineer who made a single flight into space.

heading: Deaths
txt: Victor Mature, American actor (b. 1913)

entities.title: Victor Mature
entities.description: Victor John Mature was an American stage, film, and television actor who starred most notably in several movies during the 1950s, and was known for his dark hair and smile. His best known film roles include One Million B.C. (1940), My Darling Clementine (1946), Kiss of Death (1947), Samson and Delilah (1949), and The Robe (1953). He also appeared in many musicals opposite such stars as Rita Haywor

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick Chapman Robbins, American pediatrician and virologist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1916)

entities.title: Frederick Chapman Robbins
entities.description: Frederick Chapman Robbins was an American pediatrician and virologist. He was born in Auburn, Alabama, and grew up in Columbia, Missouri, attending David H. Hickman High School.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Sherman Morgan, American chemist and engineer (b. 1921)

entities.title: Mary Sherman Morgan
entities.description: Mary Sherman Morgan was a U.S. rocket fuel scientist credited with the invention of the liquid fuel Hydyne in 1957, which powered the Jupiter-C rocket that boosted the United States' first satellite, Explorer 1.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hossein Panahi (Persian: حسین پناهی), Iranian actor and poet (b. 1956)

heading: Deaths
txt: Anatoly Larkin, Russian-American physicist and theorist (b. 1932)

entities.title: Anatoly Larkin
entities.description: Anatoly Ivanovich Larkin was a Russian theoretical physicist, universally recognised as a leader in theory of condensed matter, and who was also a celebrated teacher of several generations of theorists.

heading: Deaths
txt: Iván Szabó, Hungarian economist and politician, Minister of Finance of Hungary (b. 1934)

entities.title: Minister of Finance of Hungary
entities.description: The Minister of Finance is a member of the Hungarian cabinet and the head of the Ministry of Finance. The current minister is Mihály Varga.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lee Hazlewood, American singer-songwriter and producer (b. 1929)

entities.title: Lee Hazlewood
entities.description: Barton Lee Hazlewood was an American country and pop singer, songwriter, and record producer, most widely known for his work with guitarist Duane Eddy during the late 1950s and singer Nancy Sinatra in the 1960s and 1970s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Raul Hilberg, Austrian-American political scientist and historian (b. 1926)

heading: Deaths
txt: Craig Jones, English motorcycle racer (b. 1985)

entities.title: Craig Jones (motorcycle racer)
entities.description: Craig Jones was an English motorcycle racer. He grew up in the town of Northwich in Cheshire and attended Charles Darwin Primary School, and later Hartford High School. He died in 2008, shortly after a racing accident when he fell and was struck by another motorcycle.

heading: Deaths
txt: Blake Snyder, American screenwriter and producer (b. 1957)

entities.title: Blake Snyder
entities.description: Blake Snyder was an American screenwriter, consultant, author and educator based in Los Angeles who, through his Save the Cat trilogy of books on screenwriting and story structures, became one of the most popular writing mentors in the film industry. Snyder led international seminars and workshops for writers in various disciplines, as well as consultation sessions for some of Hollywood's largest

heading: Deaths
txt: Naoki Matsuda, Japanese footballer (b. 1977)

entities.title: Naoki Matsuda
entities.description: Naoki Matsuda  was a Japanese football player, who played as a central defender for the Japanese national team.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johnnie Bassett, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1935)

entities.title: Johnnie Bassett
entities.description: Johnnie Alexander Bassett was a Detroit-based American electric blues guitarist, singer, and songwriter. Working for decades primarily as a session musician, by the 1990s Bassett had his own backing band. He released seven albums in his lifetime. He cited Billy Butler, Tiny Grimes, Albert King, B.B. King and especially T-Bone Walker as major influences.

heading: Deaths
txt: Brian Crozier, Australian-English journalist and historian (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bud Riley, American football player and coach (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Keith H. Basso, American anthropologist and academic (b. 1940)

entities.title: Keith H. Basso
entities.description: Keith Hamilton Basso was a cultural and linguistic anthropologist noted for his study of the Western Apaches, specifically those from the community of Cibecue, Arizona. Basso was professor emeritus of anthropology at the University of New Mexico and earlier taught at the University of Arizona and Yale University.

heading: Deaths
txt: Art Donovan, American football player and radio host (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Olavi J. Mattila, Finnish engineer and politician, Finnish Minister of Foreign Affairs (b. 1918)

entities.title: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Finland)
entities.description: The Minister for Foreign Affairs handles the Finnish Government's foreign policy and relations, and is in charge of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs. The Minister for Foreign Trade and Development is also associated with this ministry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Renato Ruggiero, Italian lawyer and politician, Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs (b. 1930)

entities.title: Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs
entities.description: The Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs is the head of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Italy. The office was one of the positions which Italy inherited from the Kingdom of Sardinia where it was the most ancient ministry of the government: this origin gives to the office a ceremonial primacy in the Italian cabinet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tony Snell, English lieutenant and pilot (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: Sandy Woodward, English admiral (b. 1932)

heading: Deaths
txt: James Brady, American activist and politician, 15th White House Press Secretary (b. 1940)

entities.title: James Brady
entities.description:
James Scott Brady was an assistant to the U.S. President and the seventeenth White House Press Secretary, serving under President Ronald Reagan. In 1981, Brady became permanently disabled from a gunshot wound during the attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan.
Brady's death was ruled a homicide, caused by the gunshot wound he received 33 years earlier.

entities.title: White House Press Secretary
entities.description: The White House press secretary is a senior White House official whose primary responsibility is to act as spokesperson for the executive branch of the federal government of the United States, especially with regard to the president, senior aides and executives, as well as government policies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Chester Crandell, American lawyer and politician (b. 1946)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jake Hooker, Israeli-American guitarist and songwriter (b. 1953)

heading: Deaths
txt: Elsie Hillman, American philanthropist and politician (b. 1925)

entities.title: Elsie Hillman
entities.description: Elsie Hilliard Hillman was a Pittsburgh based philanthropist and a former Republican National Committeewoman. She was the wife of billionaire industrialist Henry Hillman. During her life, Hillman helped to advance the careers of a number of moderate Republican politicians to state and national offices. Among the politicians whose careers she fostered are President George H. W. Bush, Senator John H

heading: Deaths
txt: Les Munro, New Zealand soldier and pilot (b. 1919)

heading: Deaths
txt: John Rudometkin, American basketball player (b. 1940)

heading: Deaths
txt: Billy Sherrill, American songwriter and producer (b. 1936)

heading: Deaths
txt: Nuon Chea, Cambodian politician and theorist for the Khmer Rouge (b. 1926)

entities.title: Nuon Chea
entities.description: Nuon Chea, also known as Long Bunruot or Rungloet Laodi, was a Cambodian communist politician and revolutionary who was the chief ideologist of the Khmer Rouge. He also briefly served as acting Prime Minister of Democratic Kampuchea.He was commonly known as "Brother Number Two", as he was second-in-command to Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot, General Secretary of the Party, during the Cambodian genocide

entities.title: Democratic Kampuchea
entities.description: Kampuchea, officially from 5 January 1976 the Democratic Kampuchea, also described as the Genocidal Regime, was the Cambodian state under a one-party Marxist-Leninist totalitarian dictatorship that existed between 1975 and 1979. It was controlled by the Khmer Rouge (KR), the name popularly given to the followers of the Communist Party of Kampuchea (CPK), and was founded when KR forces defeated the

entities.title: Khmer Rouge
entities.description: The Khmer Rouge is the name that was popularly given to members of the Communist Party of Kampuchea (CPK) and by extension to the regime through which the CPK ruled Cambodia between 1975 and 1979. The name was coined in the 1960s by Norodom Sihanouk to describe his country's heterogeneous, communist-led dissidents, with whom he allied after his 1970 overthrow.
